content.description:
On the overhanging left side of the crag, this beautiful flake/layback crack is obvious. Climb the crack past a wide slot to where it ledges off at a muddy slab about 20 feet up.

Hang and drop off or downclimb; good soft sand landing.
Could be done as a short lead, but with annoying dirty topout

This obvious arete where the left and right sides of the crag join is climbed until hands are on a large finishing jug about 18 feet up. Above this a dirty, sloping slab and vegetated mud top-out discourage going higher. Begin on the right side with a long reach or possible jump to a two-handed jug; continue up using positive holds on both sides of the arete.

To get off, downclimb partway and then drop off.
Good landing with soft sand, pad helps due to height

Start down and left of the arete on a smooth, flat ledge. Work your way right and finish with High Arete.

See topo
Pad

Start at the far right end of the right-hand side of the crag where the angle changes from slabby to vertical with hands on a large and usually chalked hold. Traverse left along the base of the crag relatively easily until a blank section near the left arete (with an old broken-off piton behind one hold) can be solved statically with a high traverse on crimps or a long sideways dyno to a jug.

At the left (west) end of the highway roadcut duck into the forest and the crag is only about 20m off the road. After finishing the traverse, climb High Arete or drop off.
Soft sand landing.

At the left end of the crag where the rock veers away from the highway towards the quarry is this short overhanging cliffband. With swirly, featured gneiss rock and a pleasant forested setting, this area offers a pleasing complement to the sloughside boulders on the right side.
